education_text.0: Most of the first 16 years of Shannon's life were spent in Gaylord, where he attended public school, graduating from Gaylord High School in 1932Shannon's childhood hero was      Thomas Edison Thomas Edison, whom he later learned was a distant cousinIn 1932, Shannon entered the      University of Michigan University of Michigan, where he was introduced to the work of      George Boole George BooleIn 1936, Shannon began his graduate studies in      Electrical engineering electrical engineering at      redirect    MIT, where he worked on      Vannevar Bush Vannevar Bush's      redirect    Differential analyzer differential analyzer, an early      Analog computer analog computerIn 1940, Shannon became a National Research Fellow at the      Institute for Advanced Study Institute for Advanced Study in      Princeton, New Jersey Princeton, New JerseyThe book The Mathematical Theory of Communication reprints Shannon's 1948 article and      Warren Weaver Warren Weaver's popularization of it, which is accessible to the specialistIn 1956 Shannon joined the MIT faculty to work in the Research Laboratory of Electronics (RLE)
